title: meditate - Wiktionary, the free dictionary
cleaned_text: think or reflect upon, consider, design, purpose, intend"), in form as if frequentative of [mederi](/wiki/mederi#Latin) ("to heal, to cure, to remedy"); in sense and in form near to Greek [](/w/index.php?title=%CE%BC%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%84%E1%BF%B6&action=edit&redlink=1) (meletô, "to care for, attend to, past participle [meditated](/wiki/meditated#English)) - ( [intransitive](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#intransitive)) To [contemplate](/wiki/contemplate); to keep the mind fixed upon something; to study. - ( [intransitive](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#intransitive)) To sit or lie down and come to a deep rest while still remaining conscious. - ( [transitive](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#transitive)) To consider; to reflect on. - 1761, The Life Of Iohn[ [sic](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#sic)] Milton: - [...] yet I can by no means be persuaded that he could find leisure enough to write so many copies of it in his solitudes and sufferings, in the midst of treaties, in the hurry of removals, while he meditated his escape, and was strictly observ'd by his guards. - 1956, William Golding, [Pincher Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pincher_Martin): - He lay and meditated the sluggishness of his bowels.
